hedline.hl1: Political Briefing; A Message to Bush: Listen to Your Mama

abstract.p: Barbara Bush's statement in December 1999 that Republican Party should remove anti-abortion plank from party platform will be used in radio ad being prepared by Republicans for Choice; ad urges Gov George W Bush to 'listen to your mama'; photo (S)

block.p: In December, Barbara Bush, the former first lady and mother of Gov. George W. Bush, declared in an interview with ABC News that the Republican Party should not take a stand on abortion in its national platform. ''I believe in states' rights,'' she said, ''and I don't think it should be in the national platform. There's nothing a president can do about it anyway, in all honesty.''
Her words are about to come back to haunt her son, who has said he will fight to keep the Republican Party's anti-abortion plank at this summer's national convention.

In December, Barbara Bush, the former first lady and mother of Gov. George W. Bush, declared in an interview with ABC News that the Republican Party should not take a stand on abortion in its national platform. ''I believe in states' rights,'' she said, ''and I don't think it should be in the national platform. There's nothing a president can do about it anyway, in all honesty.''
Her words are about to come back to haunt her son, who has said he will fight to keep the Republican Party's anti-abortion plank at this summer's national convention.

Republicans for Choice, an organization that has threatened noisy, divisive demonstrations at the convention if the plank is not removed or modified, is preparing to run 30-second radio advertisements that call on Mr. Bush to ''listen to your mama'' rather than to the hard-right conservatives who tend to dominate the party's platform deliberations.

''Heed her, not Pat Robertson and Ralph Reed,'' says the advertisements' narrator, Adrian Cronauer of ''Good Morning, Vietnam'' fame. ''Listen to your mama. That's a family value we can all agree on.''
